medium: Pen and brown ink and brush and black ink wash on light tan paper, edge mounted on light tan yellow-brown laid paper
creditline: Gift of Emily Townsend Vermeule, honorary degree holder of the Class of 1989 and Cornelius Clarkson Vermeule III, in memory of Alphaeus Hyatt Mayor, Class of 1922, George Rodney Meneely, Class of 1933, and Cornelius Clarkson Vermeule, Jr., Class of 1917

bibliography.boilertext: "Acquisitions of the Art Museum 1997," in "A Window into Collecting American Folk Art: The Edward Duff Balken Collection at Princeton," special issue, Record of the Art Museum, Princeton University 57, no. 1/2 (1998): p. 164-208.
bibliography.citation: "Acquisitions of the Art Museum 1997," in "A Window into Collecting American Folk Art: The Edward Duff Balken Collection at Princeton," special issue, Record of the Art Museum, Princeton University 57, no. 1/2 (1998): p. 164-208., pp. 170–171

bibliography.boilertext: Laura Giles, Lia Markey, Claire Van Cleave, et. al., Italian Master Drawings from the Princeton University Art Museum, (Princeton, NJ: Princeton University Art Museum, 2014).
bibliography.citation: Laura Giles, Lia Markey, Claire Van Cleave, et. al., Italian Master Drawings from the Princeton University Art Museum, (Princeton, NJ: Princeton University Art Museum, 2014)., pp. 276-277, app. no. 139 (illus.)

caption: Unknown Italian artist, Hercules Slaying Cacus. Pen and brown ink and brush and black ink wash on light tan paper, edge mounted on light tan yellow-brown laid paper; 13.1 × 15.2 cm. Gift of Emily Townsend Vermeule, honorary degree holder of the Class of 1989 and Cornelius Clarkson Vermeule III, in memory of Alphaeus Hyatt Mayor, Class of 1922, George Rodney Meneely, Class of 1933, and Cornelius Clarkson Vermeule, Jr., Class of 1917 (1997-574)
